questions.stem: How can you councel a case after succesful methotrexate treatment of ectopic pregnancy?
options: No hazards of tubal block on the affected side.
Next pregnancy should be delayed for 3-6 months after treatment.
Assisted reproductive techniques should be done later to ensure intrauterine pregnancy.
Recurrence of ectopic is extremly rare.
IUCD is the preferred method for future contraception.
questions.explanation: Following successful methotrexate treatment, the textbook advises: "Subsequent pregnancy should be delayed for 3months after methotrexate.".

questions.stem: Regarding disturbed ectopic tubal pregnancy, which of the following is correct?
options: Usually associated with severe vaginal bleeding.
Snow storm appearance on ultrasound is a diagnostic feature.
questions.explanation: The textbook states that "Disturbance of pregnancy and damage of the tube occur as early as 8- 10 weeks", which falls within the first trimester.

questions.stem: The following sites of ectopic pregnancy is associated with late clinical presentation?
questions.explanation: The interstitial part of the fallopian tube is embedded within the muscular wall of the uterus, allowing it to distend more than other tubal locations before rupture, leading to a later clinical presentation.

questions.stem: An increased risk of ectopic pregnancy is met with failure of the following method of contraception:
questions.explanation: Copper IUCD, Progestin only pills, and failed Tubal sterilization are all listed risk factors for ectopic pregnancy. Since all three methods increase the risk upon their failure, "All of the above" is correct.

questions.stem: The following woman has a higher risk for ectopic pregnancy?
options: Pregnancy during irregular use of combined oral contraceptive pills.
Pregnancy on top of intrauterine contraceptive device.
Pregnancy while using chemical contraceptive spermicidal.
Previous history of polycystic ovarian disease.
questions.explanation: The textbook explicitly states that an IUCD is a risk factor because it "prevents intrauterine pregnancy not extra-uterine". Therefore, a pregnancy with an IUCD in situ has a higher chance of being ectopic.

questions.stem: The most consistent symptom of ectopic pregnancy is:
questions.explanation: The textbook states that for disturbed ectopic pregnancy, "Pain is the most prominent symptom.".

questions.stem: Regarding management of ectopic pregnancy, all of the following are true EXCEPT:
options: Laparoscopic management is allowed only to vitally stable cases.
Salpingectomy may be performed through either laparotomy or laparoscopy.
Methotrexate can be used only for some cases of undisturbed ectopic pregnancy.
Preservation of the affected tube does not affect incidence of recurrence.
Anti D is required for Rh negative cases.
questions.explanation: The textbook states that if conservative surgical treatment (salpingostomy) is performed, the "Recurrence rate is very high on the same side.". This contradicts the idea that preservation does not affect recurrence.

questions.stem: Ultrasound done for a healthy 32-year-old multipara at 10 weeks gestation, revealed a pulsating intrauterine embryo and a 3 cm clear right adnexal cyst. This cyst is:
options: Mostly functional cyst for follow up.
Combined intrauterine and extra uterine pregnancy is highly suspected.
Serum CA125 and CA19/9 should be evaluated.
Further evaluation by C.T or M.R.I should be requested.
questions.explanation: In early pregnancy, a clear adnexal cyst is highly likely to be a normal functional corpus luteum cyst, which typically requires only follow-up as it will regress spontaneously after the 10th week.

questions.stem: A P4+1 with 8 weeks amenorrhea and ultrasound showing a snow storm appearance and bilateral ovarian cysts, is mostly diagnosed as:
options: Primary uterine malignancy with ovarian metastases.
Primary ovarian malignancy with uterine involvement.
questions.explanation: The textbook describes the characteristic ultrasound finding for complete molar pregnancy as a "snowstorm appearance" and notes that "Ovarian theca lutein cysts are usually present in association with complete moles".

questions.stem: Regarding complete hydatiform mole:
options: Associated neoplastic ovarian enlargement is common.
a feto-protein is a good marker for follow after evacuation.
Uterine size is usually less than the expected for gestation.
Subsequent choriocarcinoma develops in 5-10% of cases.
questions.explanation: The textbook lists "Risk of developing Choriocarcinoma (5% of cases)" as a complication of molar pregnancy.

questions.stem: A 19 years old female with a proved diagnosis of complete vesicular mole was found to have bilateral moderate sized ovarian cysts on ultrasound. Regarding these cysts:
options: Chemotherapy is needed after evacuation of the mole to treat these cysts.
Hormone dependent and will regress spontaneously after evacuation.
Laparoscopic biopsy is needed to confirm benign nature.
Mostly is a coincidentally discovered unrelated ovarian pathology.
questions.explanation: The textbook explicitly states about these cysts: "Functional ovarian theca lutein cysts commonly occur... These theca lutein cysts will undergo spontaneous regression after molar evacuation.".

questions.stem: A 19 years old female with a proved diagnosis of complete vesicular mole of 18 weeks size and was found to have bilateral moderate sized ovarian cysts on ultrasound. Best line of treatment is:
options: Vaginal evacuation combined with laparoscopic removal of cysts.
A course of chemotherapy is needed before surgical intervention.
questions.explanation: The textbook states that "Suction evacuation: This is the gold standard technique for evacuating molar pregnancies.". The associated ovarian cysts are functional and will regress spontaneously.

questions.stem: Signs and symptoms that should alert you to the possibility of gestational trophoblastic disease include:
options: Persistent titre of hCG after pregnancy.
questions.explanation: The textbook lists a key diagnostic criterion for malignant GTD as "Abnormal high hCG levels that either rise, plateau, or fail to decrease after a recently terminated pregnancy.".

questions.stem: A 43 years old female with a proved diagnosis of complete vesicular mole of 18 weeks size and was found to have bilateral moderate sized ovarian cysts on ultrasound. The best line of treatment is:
options: A course of chemotherapy is needed before surgical intervention.
questions.explanation: For molar pregnancy, the textbook states that "Abdominal hysterectomy... is indicated only in elderly patients above 40 years with completed family.". Given the patient's age (43 years), hysterectomy is a suitable option to minimize the risk of subsequent malignancy.

questions.stem: All the followings are complications of molar pregnancy EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: The textbook lists complications including hyperemesis, hyperthyroidism, PIH, and infection. It mentions the risk of trophoblastic neoplasms (choriocarcinoma), but not uterine adenocarcinoma.

questions.stem: Regarding partial vesicular mole:
options: There is duplication of the paternal chromosomes.
Pregnancy is allowed to proceed to near term.
questions.explanation: The textbook indicates that the "Risk of developing an invasive Mole" is "4% in a partial moles", which is significantly lower than for a complete mole.

questions.stem: The diagnosis of vesicular mole, all of the followings are true EXCEPT:
options: The condition is more common in extremes of reproductive age.
Uterus is doughy and commonly larger than expected.
Passage of vesicles during examination is diagnostic.
Ultrasonography shows theca lutein cysts in 20% of cases.
questions.explanation: The textbook states that "Functional ovarian theca lutein cysts commonly occur in 25-60 % of complete moles". Therefore, stating they occur in only "20% of cases" is incorrect.

questions.stem: Regarding management of vesicular mole all of the followings are true EXCEPT:
options: Suction evacuation is done in the majority of cases.
Hysterectomy is indicated in elderly to minimize risk of subsequent malignancy.
Hysterotomy is indicated in large uterus with severe bleeding.
Follow up by B-HCG is indicated in some cases
questions.explanation: Intensive and prolonged follow-up with β-hCG is mandatory for all cases of molar pregnancy to detect persistent trophoblastic disease, not just "some cases."

questions.stem: The genetic composition of a complete molar pregnancy is:
questions.explanation: The textbook states that a complete mole "originates from fertilization of an empty ovum. Duplication of the DNA of one sperm resulting in a 46 XX karyotype". None of the provided options match the typical 46 XX genetic composition.

collectionQuizzes.title: NORMAL AND ABNORMAL LABOR AND DELIVERY

quizData.title: NORMAL AND ABNORMAL LABOR AND DELIVERY

questions.stem: The relation of the fetal parts to one another determines which of the following?
questions.explanation: Fetal attitude specifically refers to the relation of the fetal parts to each other, such as whether they are in a state of flexion or extension.

questions.stem: Regarding physiology of labor, all the followings are true ЕХСЕРТ:
options: Prodromal stage and latent phase of true labor are overlapping and difficult to distinguish clearly.
Braxton Hicks contractions are present in late pregnancy and continue to false labor pains then true labor pains.
False labor pains are relieved by analgesics and antispasmodics.
Progesterone withdrawal is the main cause of onset of labor in human.
Show of labor denotes starting shearing movement between lower segment and amniotic membranes.
questions.explanation: The textbook lists progesterone withdrawal as one of several theories and hypotheses for the onset of labor, explicitly stating that the exact cause is unknown. Therefore, claiming it is the main cause is not supported as true by the text.

questions.stem: A sure evidence of onset of labor is:
options: Expulsion of mucus streaked with blood (Show).
questions.explanation: A sure evidence of the onset of labor is progressive cervical dilatation. True labor is fundamentally defined by regular uterine contractions that result in timely cervical effacement and dilatation, differentiating it from false labor pains where these cervical changes are absent.

questions.stem: The following is characteristic of true labor pains:
options: Increasing in frequency, duration and strength.
Starts when the cervix is 3 cm dilated.
Usually coincide with rupture of membranes.
Pains are relieved by sedatives and antispasmodics.
questions.explanation: True labor pains are characterized by gradually increasing in frequency, amplitude (strength), and duration, with shorter resting periods between contractions. Unlike false labor pains, true labor pains are not relieved by sedatives.

questions.stem: Prodromal stage of labor is characterized by:
questions.explanation: The prodromal stage of labor is specifically characterized by pelvic pressure symptoms.

questions.stem: A partogram is used for assessment of:
questions.explanation: A partogram is used as a graphic record to monitor the progress of labor, specifically allowing an instant visual assessment of the rate of cervical dilatation and effacement, and the descent of the fetal head. It is a tool for early diagnosis of prolonged or abnormal labor.

questions.stem: External cardiotocography (CTG) is used for assessment of:
questions.explanation: External cardiotocography (CTG) is used for continuous electronic FHR (fetal heart rate) monitoring during labor, primarily to assess fetal wellbeing, particularly in high-risk pregnancies.

questions.stem: Progress of first stage of normal labor is characterized by:
options: Engagement of fetal head must occur before full cervical dilatation.
Rate of cervical dilatation is the same through 1st stage.
In primipara, effacement of the cervix occurs before dilatation.
Duration till full cervical dilatation is usually less than 3 hours.
Membranes should be intact till full cervical dilatation.
questions.explanation: In a primigravida, the progress of the first stage of normal labor is characterized by the effacement of the cervix occurring before dilatation. The rate of cervical dilatation is not uniform throughout the first stage, as it has a slow latent phase and a rapid active phase.

questions.stem: In management of 2nd stage of normal labor:
options: Patient should be instructed not to push down.
Posterior shoulder is delivered 1st after head expulsion.
Head is allowed to extend before crowning.
Episiotomy is routinely done in primipara.
questions.explanation: In the management of the second stage of normal labor, after the fetal head has been delivered, the posterior shoulder is delivered first by lateral flexion of the spine. Maternal bearing down efforts are encouraged during this stage, and the head should not be allowed to extend before crowning to minimize perineal tears. Episiotomy is performed when needed, not routinely.

questions.stem: The following is best used in intra-partum assessment of fetal wellbeing?
questions.explanation: For intra-partum assessment of fetal wellbeing, continuous electronic FHR monitoring by Cardiotocography (CTG) is a key method, particularly indicated in high-risk pregnancies. Doppler study, non-stress test, and biophysical profile are primarily methods for antepartum fetal surveillance.

questions.stem: Head is delivered by extension in:
options: After coming head in breech sacro anterior position.
questions.explanation: In the mechanism of delivery for a Direct Occipito Anterior (DOA) position, the head is delivered by a movement of extension, where the sub-occipital region hinges under the symphysis pubis.

questions.stem: Head is delivered by flexion in:
questions.explanation: In a Direct Occipito Posterior (DOP) position, the head is delivered by a movement of flexion, often described as 'face to pubis' delivery.

questions.stem: The second stage of labor is defined as which of the following?
options: The interval from onset of contractions to the beginning of cervical dilation.
The time from full cervical dilation to delivery of the fetus.
The duration of maternal pushing efforts.
The time from delivery of the fetus until delivery of the placenta.
The time from delivery of the placenta to discharge from the hospital.
questions.explanation: The second stage of labor is defined as the period that starts by full cervical dilatation (10 cm) and ends with the complete expulsion of the fetus.

questions.stem: A sure diagnosis of 2nd stage of labor is:
questions.explanation: The second stage of labor is definitively diagnosed by full cervical dilatation (10 cm).

questions.stem: The following is true about normal labor:
options: The active phase of labor starts at 2 cm dilatation.
The rate of cervical dilatation is 1 cm/ hour in multigravidas.
The average duration of the third stage of labor is 1-2 hours.
The duration of the latent phase is 4 hours in primigravidas.
The rate of cervical dilatation is 1 cm / hour in primigravidas.
questions.explanation: In the active phase of the first stage of labor, the rate of cervical dilatation is stated as 1.2 cm/hour in primigravidas (PGDA). While 1 cm/hour is a slight approximation, it is the most accurate statement among the given options, as the active phase starts at 4 cm, the rate for multigravidas is 1.5 cm/hour, and the third stage is 10-30 minutes.

questions.stem: During labor, station (+1) means:
options: Bipareital diameter is at level of ischial spines.
Vault is felt below ischial tuberosity.
Biparietal diameter is below level of pelvic inlet.
questions.explanation: During labor, station 0 indicates that the head is engaged, with the biparietal diameter (BPD) passing the plane of the pelvic inlet and the vault felt at the ischial spines. Therefore, a positive station such as (+1) signifies further descent, meaning the biparietal diameter is below the level of the pelvic inlet.

questions.stem: Which of the following is not used to calculate the Bishop score?
questions.explanation: The Bishop score is calculated based on cervical length, cervical dilatation, cervical consistency, cervical position, and the station of the fetal head. Parity is not a parameter used to calculate the Bishop score.

questions.stem: On auscultating maternal abdomen during pregnancy/labor, all the followings sounds could be present EXCЕРТ:
options: Umbilical vessels pulsations coinciding with fetal heart rate.
Uterine vessels pulsations coinciding with maternal pulse rate.
questions.explanation: When auscultating the maternal abdomen during pregnancy or labor, maternal heart sounds are not typically heard as a distinct finding in the way fetal heart sounds, umbilical vessel pulsations (funic souffle), uterine vessel pulsations (uterine souffle), or maternal intestinal sounds might be. Maternal heart sounds are usually assessed directly over the chest.

questions.stem: Regarding management of 1st stage of labor, choose the correct statement:
options: Nutrition by IV fluids in active phase of labor.
Rectal enema is avoided to prevent contamination.
questions.explanation: In the management of the first stage of labor, nutrition with oral fluids, juices, or intravenous (IV) fluids is advised to prevent hypoglycemia. Analgesics are used for pain relief, bearing down efforts are discouraged in the first stage, and evacuation of the bladder and rectum is part of patient preparation.

questions.stem: Complication of epidural anesthesia during labor include:
options: Loss of auxiliary force of labor.
questions.explanation: A complication of epidural analgesia during labor is a loss of the urge for straining, which is an auxiliary force of labor. This can increase the duration of the first and second stages of labor and raise the need for instrumental delivery.

questions.stem: The following is considered an alarming sign during labor:
options: Escape of a thick mucus plug streaked with blood in early labor.
Passage of thick meconium after membranes rupture in cephalic presentation.
questions.explanation: In a cephalic presentation, the passage of meconium after membranes rupture is considered an alarming sign during labor because it denotes fetal hypoxia and acidosis. A fetal heart rate of 120-160 beats/minute is considered normal.

questions.stem: A primipara during labor with a 4cm dilated cervix, 60 % effaced, intact membranes and fetal head at 0 station, occipito-anterior position. After 1 hour, cervix becomes 6 cm dilated, 90% effaced, still intact membranes and head at same station. How can you describe this labor course?
questions.explanation: The patient is a primipara in the active phase of labor (starting at 4 cm dilatation). She dilated from 4 cm to 6 cm in one hour, which is a rate of 2 cm/hour. Given that the normal rate of cervical dilatation for a primigravida in the active phase is 1.2 cm/hour, this rate indicates normal progress of labor.

questions.stem: During management of the 2nd stage of normal labor, if the head is allowed to extend after crowning, vulva will be maximally distended by:
questions.explanation: During the management of the second stage of normal labor, when the head is allowed for gradual extension after crowning, the vulva will be maximally distended by the suboccipito-frontal diameter (SOF), which measures 10 cm.

questions.stem: During management of 2nd stage of normal labor, if the head is allowed to extend before crowning, vulva will be maximally distended by:
questions.explanation: If the head is allowed to extend before crowning during the second stage of labor, the vulva will be maximally distended by the occipito-frontal diameter (OFD), which measures 11.5 cm. This larger diameter increases the liability to perineal tears.

questions.stem: All of the following are indications for episiotomy during labor EXCEРТ:
questions.explanation: All the listed options are indications for episiotomy, EXCEPT for Direct Mento-Posterior (DMP) face presentation. In DMP, the head cannot be delivered vaginally due to the inability to flex or extend further, resulting in an obstructed labor that typically requires a Cesarean section, not an episiotomy for vaginal delivery.

questions.stem: Regarding management of second stage of normal labor;
options: Fundal pressure is mandatory to help fetal head expulsion.
Head is allowed to extend after crowning.
Perineal support should be maintained till full fetal body extraction.
questions.explanation: In the management of the second stage of normal labor, the head is allowed for gradual extension after crowning with adequate perineal support to prevent sudden expulsion and perineal tears. Maternal bearing down is encouraged during this stage, and episiotomy is performed when needed, not routinely.

questions.stem: A transverse groove seen on the lower abdomen in a woman during labor could be due to any of the following EXСЕРТ:
options: Bandl's ring (pathological retraction ring) in obstructed labor
questions.explanation: A transverse groove seen on the lower abdomen during labor could be due to a full urinary bladder, an associated uterine fibroid, an ovarian tumor, or Bandl's ring (pathological retraction ring) in obstructed labor. However, a constriction (contraction) ring is typically not seen abdominally and is only felt vaginally.

questions.stem: During 3rd stage of normal labor, signs of placental separation include:
options: Patient had a reflex bearing down.
questions.explanation: During the third stage of normal labor, one of the classic signs of placental separation and descent is the elongation of the umbilical cord. Other signs include a gush of blood and a suprapubic bulge.

questions.stem: In management of third stage of normal labor:
options: Conservative management is associated with less risk of post-partum hemorrhage.
Duration till placental delivery should not exceed ½ an hour.
Estimated blood loss from placental site is about 1 liter.
Ritgen maneuver may be used to enhance placental separation.
Manual separation of placenta is routinely done.
questions.explanation: In the management of the third stage of normal labor, the duration until placental delivery should ideally range from 10 to 30 minutes, especially with active management. Active management aims to reduce blood loss, implying conservative management would not have less risk of PPH. Ritgen's maneuver is for fetal head delivery, not placental separation, and manual separation is for retained placenta, not routine.

questions.stem: In active management of third stage of normal labor:
options: Retained undiagnosed 2nd twin pregnancy may occur.
Duration till placental delivery should not exceed 1 hour.
Estimated blood loss from placental site is about 1 liter.
Steady cord traction is done before uterine contraction to enhance placental separation.
Manual separation of placenta is routinely done.
questions.explanation: In active management of the third stage of normal labor, a potential, though rare, complication is the risk of a retained undiagnosed second twin pregnancy. Active management involves the use of ecbolics to promote uterine contractions, and if a second twin is not suspected or diagnosed, it could potentially be retained. The typical duration of the third stage is 10-30 minutes, and cord traction is performed during uterine contractions, not before.

questions.stem: During the 3rd stage of normal labor, signs of placental separation include:
options: Patient had an involuntary bearing down.
Elongation of the cord that recedes back.
questions.explanation: During the third stage of normal labor, a sign of placental separation is a gush of blood, which manifests as vaginal bleeding. Other signs include elongation of the umbilical cord and a suprapubic bulge.

questions.stem: The following sign is related to placental separation in the third stage of labor:
options: Recession of the umbilical cord occurs.
questions.explanation: A sign related to placental separation in the third stage of labor is the presence of a suprapubic bulge, which occurs as the placenta descends into and fills the lower uterine segment.

questions.stem: A healthy 23yrs old G1P0 has had an uncomplicated pregnancy to date, presents as she is 40wks and still hasn't delivered. She reports good fetal movements. On PV, her cervix was firm, posterior, 50%effaced, and 1cm dilated, the vertex is station -1. Estimated fetal weight is 3200 gm. The recommended immediate management is:
options: Induction of labor by vaginal misoprostol.
Start oxytocin infusion after artificial rupture of membranes.
Continue fetal kick count monitoring and recheck after 1 week.
Check fetal lung maturation before making an action.
questions.explanation: The patient is at 40 weeks gestation, which is not yet considered a post-term pregnancy (defined as > 42 weeks). Given the reassuring good fetal movements and an unfavorable cervix (Bishop score likely <5), the recommended immediate management is expectant management by continuing fetal kick count monitoring and rechecking after 1 week, as there are no indications for immediate induction or Cesarean section.

questions.stem: Administration of pethidine injections less than two hours before delivery may be complicated by:
options: Motor block with weakness of lower limbs.
questions.explanation: Administration of pethidine injections less than two hours before delivery may be complicated by neonatal respiratory depression.

questions.stem: The following is best used in intra-partum assessment of fetal wellbeing?
questions.explanation: For intra-partum assessment of fetal wellbeing, especially when fetal distress is suspected, fetal scalp pH is considered a definitive diagnostic method. A blood sample is taken from the fetal scalp during labor to measure the pH, with a pH below 7.25 indicating fetal asphyxia due to hypoxia and acidosis.

questions.stem: All the following are possible complications of artificial rupture of membranes during labor EXCЕРТ:
questions.explanation: Possible complications of artificial rupture of membranes (amniotomy) during labor include placental abruption (accidental hemorrhage), vaginal bleeding and fetal injury, cord prolapse, and infection. Meconium aspiration is a consequence of fetal distress, which can be caused or exacerbated by complications like cord prolapse, but it is not a direct complication of the procedure of rupturing the membranes itself.

questions.stem: Elderly primigravida is at increased risk of:
questions.explanation: An elderly primigravida is at an increased liability to medical disorders during pregnancy, including preeclampsia (PE), eclampsia, and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).

questions.stem: Grand multipara is at increased risk of:
questions.explanation: A grand multipara is at an increased liability to rupture of the uterus, which can be due to factors such as oversized babies with malposition and malpresentations, or osteomalacia affecting the bony pelvis.

questions.stem: A primipara during labor, cervix is 1cm dilated, 60 % effaced. Membranes are intact and head is occipito-anterior position at 0 station. After 2 hours, cervical dilatation is the same, 90% effaced, still intact membranes and head at same station. How can you describe this labor course?
questions.explanation: The patient is in the latent phase of labor, which is characterized by slow and variable progress in cervical dilatation and effacement. While dilatation remained at 1 cm for 2 hours, there was significant progress in effacement from 60% to 90%. This progression in effacement, within the context of the highly variable and slow latent phase, indicates normal progress for this stage of labor.

questions.stem: A 23years old G2P2 has had an uncomplicated pregnancy to date. She is 42wks and still had not delivered. She reports good fetal movements. Cervix is soft, central, 50%effaced, and 2 cm dilated. The vertex is at zero station and estimated fetal weight is 3200 gm. What is the recommended management for this case?
options: Induction of labor by vaginal misoprostol.
Oxytocin infusion and artificial rupture of membranes.
Continue fetal kick count monitoring and recheck after 1 week.
Check fetal lung maturation before making an action.
questions.explanation: The patient is at 42 weeks gestation, which is considered a post-term pregnancy. Her cervix has a favorable Bishop score (soft, central, 50% effaced, 2 cm dilated, vertex at 0 station), indicating it is ripe enough for induction without requiring cervical ripening agents like misoprostol. Given these factors, oxytocin infusion and artificial rupture of membranes (amniotomy) is the recommended management to induce labor.

questions.stem: The average blood loss during normal deliveries is:
questions.explanation: Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as excessive blood loss greater than 500 ml following a vaginal delivery. This definition implies that the average blood loss during normal vaginal deliveries is generally up to 500 ml.

questions.stem: The average blood loss during uncomplicated cesarean section is:
options: The same as normal vaginal delivery with episiotomy.
questions.explanation: Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is defined as excessive blood loss after delivery, with a threshold of greater than 1000 ml following a Cesarean section. Therefore, the average blood loss during an uncomplicated Cesarean section is typically around 1000 ml.

questions.stem: The most important hemostatic mechanism to control blood loss after vaginal delivery:
options: Tourniquet effect of interlacing oblique uterine muscle bundles.
Increased blood clotting factors in pregnancy.
Markedly decreased blood pressure in uterine venules.
questions.explanation: The most important hemostatic mechanism to control blood loss after vaginal delivery is the tourniquet effect of the interlacing oblique uterine muscle bundles. Sustained myometrial contractions and retraction are crucial for placental separation and for compressing the blood vessels in the placental bed to prevent postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.stem: Which options describes the proper order of the cardinal movements of labor?
questions.explanation: The proper order of the cardinal movements of labor for the fetal head in occipito-anterior position typically follows this sequence: Engagement, followed by Flexion, then Internal Rotation, and finally Extension for delivery of the head. Descent is a continuous process that occurs throughout these movements.

questions.stem: A31-year old primigravida at 39 weeks gestation complains of painful uterine contractions that are occurring every 3 to 4 minutes. Her cervix has changed from 1 cm to 2 cm dilatation over 1 hour. The following management plans is most appropriate?
questions.explanation: The patient is a primigravida at 39 weeks who is in the latent phase of labor, characterized by slow and variable progress in cervical dilatation. Since there is no indication of fetal distress or other complications warranting immediate intervention, the most appropriate management plan is observation for uterine contractions and the natural progression of labor.

questions.stem: A24 year old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks gestation presents with painful uterine contractions and passage of darkvaginal blood mixed with some mucous. What is the most likely cause of this blood?
questions.explanation: The presentation of painful uterine contractions with the passage of dark vaginal blood mixed with mucus is most likely indicative of bloody show. This phenomenon occurs in early labor as the cervix softens, effaces, and dilates, leading to the expulsion of the cervical mucus plug, often tinged with blood from ruptured capillaries.

questions.stem: How you describe cervical dilatation of 1 cm/h in nulliparous women and 1.5 cm/h in multiparous women?
questions.explanation: A cervical dilatation rate of 1.2 cm/hour in primigravidas (nulliparous women) and 1.5 cm/hour in multigravidas (multiparous women) is characteristic of the active phase of true labor, which begins after 4 cm dilatation.

questions.stem: Regarding moulding of fetal head, choose the correct statement:
options: Parietal bones do not overlap each other.
Parietal bones may overlap frontal bones.
Should be associated with caput succedaneum.
Occurs rapidly in after-coming head of breech presentation.
Marked degree increases fetal risk of intracranial hemorrhage.
questions.explanation: A marked degree of moulding increases the fetal risk of intracranial hemorrhage due to excessive compression of the cranial bones. Moulding involves the overlapping of fetal skull bones, such as one parietal bone overriding another or over the occipital bone.

questions.stem: Cervical caput during labor denotes:
questions.explanation: While the textbook does not explicitly define 'cervical caput,' if it refers to edema or swelling of the cervical tissue during labor despite adequate contractions, it would typically denote a failure of the cervix to dilate effectively, which is known as cervical dystocia. The text mentions 'Edematous vagina' in obstructed labor.

questions.stem: Regarding meconium stained liquor; all the followings are true EXCЕРТ:
options: Normal finding in breech presentation due to mechanical compression.
Thin meconium stained liquor in cephalic presentation indicates fetal monitoring.
Thick meconium stained liquor in cephalic presentation indicates fetal distress.
Fetal hypoxia induces vagal stimulation with increased intestinal peristaltic movement and relaxation of anal sphincter.
Once delivery occurs; no neonatal hazards.
questions.explanation: All the listed statements about meconium-stained liquor are true, EXCEPT that there are no neonatal hazards once delivery occurs. Meconium aspiration can lead to significant neonatal complications, and clearing the infant's airway is an immediate therapy for suspected meconium aspiration, highlighting the potential hazards.

questions.stem: Immediate therapy for infants with suspected meconium aspiration should be:
questions.explanation: The immediate therapy for infants with suspected meconium aspiration should be clearing of the airway.

questions.stem: The incidence of occipto-posterior at time of delivery is:
questions.explanation: The textbook states that Occipito Posterior (OP) positions are encountered in around 20% of cases at the onset of labor. While this is at onset and not delivery, and the textbook also indicates that 90% of OP cases convert to OA during labor, in the absence of a more precise figure for 'at time of delivery,' 25% is the closest option to the initial incidence mentioned.

questions.stem: The commonest cause of occipto-posterior position is
questions.explanation: A common cause of occipito-posterior position is related to pelvic shape, specifically an android or anthropoid pelvis, where the heart-shaped inlet allows the larger biparietal diameter (BPD) to occupy the wider hind-pelvis, and the narrower fore-pelvis (pelvis with narrow fore pelvis) accommodates the smaller bitemporal diameter (BTD).

questions.stem: Which of the following suggests occipito-posterior malposition in examination?
options: Abdomen looks flattened below the umbilicus.
Fetal head tends to be smaller in pelvic grip.
Fetal limbs are felt in midline.
Fetal heart is auscultated in flanks away from midline.
questions.explanation: The provided textbook excerpts do not contain specific information regarding the physical examination findings (such as flattened abdomen, fetal head size in pelvic grip, fetal limb position, or fetal heart sound location) that specifically suggest occipito-posterior malposition. Therefore, this question cannot be answered using the provided sources.

questions.stem: Watchful expectancy in occipito-posterior malposition up to 2 hours in the 2nd stage of labor aims to:
options: Long anterior rotation of occiput 3/8 of a circle occurs.
Excessive head moulding to pass the pelvis with the larger diameter.
Yielding of the pelvis with increased pelvic inlet diameter.
questions.explanation: Watchful expectancy in occipito-posterior malposition during labor primarily aims for long anterior rotation of the occiput 3/8 of a circle to a direct occipito-anterior (DOA) position, which occurs in over 90% of cases. This rotation allows for a normal vaginal delivery via extension, although it may prolong the second stage of labor.

questions.stem: All the following regarding occipito posterior position are true EXCЕРТ:
options: During face to pubis delivery, the perineum is distended by the occipito-frontal.
Deep transverse arrest can be managed by vacuum extraction.
The progress of labor depends on the degree ofhead flexion.
Android pelvis is a rare cause.
During labor, 90% of the cases deliver spontaneously as occipito anterior.
questions.explanation: All the listed statements are true regarding occipito-posterior position, EXCEPT that an android pelvis is a rare cause. The textbook explicitly lists android or anthropoid pelvis as a cause of occipito-posterior malposition due to its specific inlet shape.

questions.stem: Correction of head deflexion in occipito-posterior position is favored by:
questions.explanation: Correction of head deflexion and subsequent internal rotation in occipito-posterior position is favored by strong uterine contractions. Other favoring factors include an adequate pelvis and good pelvic floor musculature.

questions.stem: In occipito-posterior malposition in labor, deflexion of fetal head is due to:
options: Biparietal diameter occupies sacro-cotyloid pelvic diameter.
Biparietal diameter occupies oblique pelvic diameter.
Bitemporal diameter occupies transverse pelvic diameter.
Bitemporal diameter occupies sacro-cotyloid pelvic diameter.
Hypertonicity of fetal neck extensor muscles.
questions.explanation: In occipito-posterior malposition, deflexion of the fetal head can be due to the biparietal diameter (BPD) occupying the sacro-cotyloid pelvic diameter. This occurs in pelvis types like the android pelvis, where the heart-shaped inlet causes the wider BPD to engage in the hind-pelvis and the narrower bitemporal diameter in the fore-pelvis, predisposing to deflexion.

questions.stem: Regarding mechanism of delivery in occipito anterior position:
options: Descent through the birth canal occurs in the 2nd stage only.
Bitemporal diameter is the engaging diameter.
Long internal rotation of occiput occurs before correction of deflexion.
Long internal rotation of shoulders should follows long head rotation.
Flexion is the movement by which the head is delivered in most cases.
questions.explanation: In the mechanism of delivery in occipito-anterior position, external rotation of the fetal head is due to the internal rotation of the anterior shoulder. This means that the internal rotation of the shoulders occurs in sequence after the primary internal rotation of the head, causing the head's external rotation. Descent is continuous through both stages, BPD is the engaging diameter, flexion precedes internal rotation, and the head is delivered by extension.

questions.stem: Aprimigravida in the 2nd stage of labor for the past 2 hours with adequate uterine contractions, with the fetus in left occipito-posterior position at station-1. The best way to manage would be:
questions.explanation: The patient is a primigravida who has reached the maximum normal duration of 2 hours in the second stage of labor. The fetus is in a left occipito-posterior (LOP) position, and critically, the head is at station -1, meaning it is not engaged. Instrumental deliveries (vacuum or forceps) are contraindicated if the head is not engaged. Given the prolonged second stage, unengaged head, and OP malposition in a primigravida, Cesarean delivery is the safest and most appropriate management.

questions.stem: The following factors favors long internal rotation of the fetal head in occipito- posterior EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Factors favoring long internal rotation of the fetal head in an occipito-posterior position include correction of deflexion, strong uterine contractions, an adequate pelvis (like a gynecoid pelvis), good pelvic floor musculature, and adequate amniotic fluid. Multiparity is not listed as a favoring factor; rather, issues like pendulous abdomen and weak abdominal muscles in grand multipara can contribute to malpositions.

questions.stem: Which of the followings prevents long internal rotation of fetal occiput in occipito-posterior malposition?
questions.explanation: Epidural anesthesia can indirectly prevent long internal rotation of the fetal occiput in occipito-posterior malposition by leading to a loss of the urge for straining and potentially affecting the strength of uterine contractions. Weak uterine contractions are listed as a factor interfering with internal rotation.

questions.stem: A28 year-old primigravida, 37week's gestation in the second stage of labor for 45 minutes. Pelvis is adequate, membranes are ruptured, foetal head is in ROPposition, +2 station. The foetal heart rate is 120/min and the mother is exhausted. The most appropriate management is:
questions.explanation: The patient is a primigravida in the second stage of labor with an engaged and descended fetal head (+2 station), ROP malposition, and maternal exhaustion. While the FHR is reassuring, maternal exhaustion warrants intervention to shorten the second stage. Vacuum extraction (ventouse) is an appropriate instrumental delivery method for occipito-posterior positions to aid rotation and descent of the head, with generally less injury to the maternal birth canal compared to forceps.

questions.stem: Aprimigravida with occipito-posterior malposition during labor. Cervix is fully dilated; head is 0 station, ruptured membranes with clear liquor. uterine contractions are infrequent. The best management would be:
options: Avoid bearing down and give sedation.
Oxytocin and wait for spontaneous rotation.
questions.explanation: The patient, a primigravida with occipito-posterior malposition, has a fully dilated cervix and an engaged head, but her uterine contractions are infrequent. This indicates hypotonic uterine inertia. The best management is to augment labor with oxytocin infusion to achieve adequate contractions and then wait for spontaneous rotation of the head, as 90% of OP cases rotate anteriorly and deliver vaginally.

questions.stem: A primigravida with occipito-posterior malposition during labor. Cervix is 8cm dilated, head at -2 station with mild pelvic caput. Membranes ruptured spontaneously with thick green liquor and uterine contractions are infrequent. The best management would be:
questions.explanation: The patient is a primigravida with thick green liquor, which is a strong indicator of fetal distress. Furthermore, her cervix is not fully dilated (8 cm), and the head is not engaged (-2 station), making instrumental delivery unsuitable. In cases of fetal distress with a non-fully dilated cervix, immediate Cesarean section is the indicated management.

questions.stem: Aprimigravida with occipito-posterior malposition during labor. Cervix is 7cm dilated, head at 0 station, membranes ruptured spontaneously with clear liquor and uterine contractions are infrequent. What is the best management?
questions.explanation: The patient is a primigravida in the active phase of labor (7 cm dilated, head at 0 station) with occipito-posterior malposition and infrequent uterine contractions. This presentation suggests hypotonic uterine inertia. The best management for hypotonic inertia is to augment labor with oxytocin infusion to establish adequate contractions and promote labor progress.

questions.stem: Regarding direct occipito posterior malposition during labor:
options: Marked deflexion causes the sinciput to reach the pelvic floor first.
Occiput rotates 1/8 of a circle anteriorly.
Vulva is distended with suboccipito-frontal diameter.
questions.explanation: In direct occipito-posterior (DOP) malposition, marked deflexion is present, causing the sinciput to reach the pelvic floor first. This type of malposition accounts for about 6% of OP cases, where the occiput rotates posteriorly 1/8 of a circle, and the head is delivered in flexion.

questions.stem: Regarding direct occipito posterior malposition during labor:
options: More common to occur in preterm labors.
Sudden head compression and decompression may occur.
questions.explanation: In direct occipito-posterior malposition, the head is delivered by flexion ('face to pubis'), and the vulva is distended by the occipito-frontal diameter (11.5 cm). This larger distending diameter, compared to a normal occipito-anterior delivery, often leads to common vulval lacerations and necessitates an episiotomy.

questions.stem: Indications of caesarean section in occipito-posterior position include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: All the listed options are indications for Cesarean section in occipito-posterior position, EXCEPT for face to pubis delivery. Face to pubis delivery is a mechanism of vaginal delivery (in flexion) that can occur in some occipito-posterior cases, although it often requires an episiotomy due to the larger diameter distending the vulva.

questions.stem: Regarding face malpresentation:
options: Anencephally and cystic hygroma should be excluded in 1ry face presentation.
Direct mento-posterior is delivered in flexion.
In mento-anterior position, fetal back is directed anterior either to Lt or Rt side.
By PV, it could be confused with cases of complete breech.
questions.explanation: Regarding face malpresentation, it is possible that on vaginal examination (PV), it could be confused with a complete breech presentation due to the need to differentiate the bony landmarks of the chin and mouth from the sacrum and ischial tuberosities, especially if the fetal face is distorted or edematous. Anencephaly is a listed etiology, but not cystic hygroma. Direct mento-posterior is not delivered in flexion, and only about 2/3 of mento-posterior cases rotate anteriorly.

questions.stem: Regarding face malpresentation:
options: Direct mento-anterior is delivered in extension.
Mento-anterior delivery is considered normal delivery
Direct mento-posterior should be managed by cesarean section.
Correction to vertex presentation may be tried in some cases.
Vaccum extraction could be used if labor is prolonged.

questions.stem: Regarding face presentation, choose the correct answer:
options: The engaging diameter is the mento -vertical diameter.
Increased risk of fetal congenital anomalies.
The diameter distending the vulva is the submento -bregmatic diameter.

questions.stem: Which of the following describes a frank breech?
options: Flexion of the hips and extension of the knees.
Flexion of the hips and flexion of the knees.
Extension of the hips and flexion of the knees.
Extension of the hips and extension the knees.
Lower extremities flexed at the hips and knees flexed.

questions.stem: In which of the following condition vaginal delivery is contraindicated?
Which of the following is an indication of C.S in breech delivery?
options: Estimated fetal weight is between 2.5 kg to 3.5 kg.
Extended fetal neck as detected by ultrasound.

questions.stem: The following is encouraging for a trial of vaginal delivery in breech presentation:
options: Estimated fetal weight is between 1.5 kg to 2 kg.
Buttocks are felt at level of pelvic brim.
Extended fetal head as detected by ultrasound.

questions.stem: A P2+2 with previous precipitate vaginal deliveries, 38 weeks gestation presents for ANC. Examination and US show complete breech presentation +/- 3 kg, fundal posterior placenta and AFI: 15. What is your suggested management?
options: Wait for spontaneous onset of labor.

questions.stem: In Assisted Breech delivery:
options: Traction on fetal trunk should be done to assist fetal head delivery.
Prague maneuver is routinely used to deliver the after coming head.
Fetal back should be kept anterior.
Once the fetal neck appears under symphysis, fetal body should be lifted towards mother's abdomen.
Episiotomy is usually done after delivering the fetal body.

questions.stem: Regarding assisted breech delivery:
options: Baby is delivered spontaneously till the fetal head.
Fetal body should be covered with warm towels to avoid premature respiration.
Moulding of the fetal head is delayed.
After-coming head is delivered in extension.
Cord prolapse is more common in frank breech.

questions.stem: Which type of breech presentation with highest incidence of cord prolapse?
Which type of breech presentation with least incidence of cord prolapse?
Regarding retained after-coming head of breech presentation:
options: In preterm breech, the head may be entrapped in incompletely dilated cervix.
Previous cephalic delivery minimizes the risk of retained after-coming head.
Urgent cesarean delivery is the suitable management.

questions.stem: The following can predispose to retained after-coming head in breech presentation?
options: Traction on fetal body during assisted breech delivery.

questions.stem: What is commonest type of monozygotic twins?
Regarding monozygotic twins, if splitting of the fertilized ovum occurs during 1 2 days of fertilization, the resultant twins will be:

A patient had just delivered her first twin vaginally at 37 weeks. PV examination reveals a fully dilated cervix and a shoulder presenting second twin with bulging amniotic sac. Fetal heart rate is reassuring. The appropriate management?
options: External cephalic version and wait for spontaneous cephalic delivery.
Amniotomy, internal podalic version & breech extraction.
No action & wait for spontaneous expulsion.

questions.stem: Obstetric ultrasound in twin pregnancy can identify all of the following EXCEPT:
Multifetal gestations have a higher risk of all the following EXCЕРТ:

A full term primipara with twin pregnancy presents after delivery of first twin vaginally at home an hour ago. PV reveals a fully dilated cervix and a shoulder presenting second twin with drained liquor. The appropriate management is:
options: External cephalic version and wait for spontaneous cephalic delivery.
No action & wait for spontaneous expulsion.

questions.stem: Transverse lie in a full-term multipara in labor, is most commonly managed by:
options: Internal podalic version and breech extraction.

questions.stem: In a multipara at 32 weeks; transverse lie is diagnosed by US during routine ANC. Best management is:
options: Internal podalic version and breech extraction.

questions.stem: Regarding a case of neglected shoulder:
options: External cephalic version is a safe option.
Internal podalic version may be done in selected cases.
Low vertical cesarean section is preferably done.
Easy fetal extraction in transverse lower segment incision.

questions.stem: Which of the followings predisposes to cord prolapse:
options: Coiling of the cord around fetal neck.

questions.stem: Regarding cord prolapse, one of the following is correct:
options: In breech presentation, it is most likely with frank breech.
Urgent cesarean delivery is indicated regardless pulsations.
Reposition of the cord in the vagina has no value in decreasing fetal mortality.
Patient should be positioned in semi-sitting position.

questions.stem: Regarding occult cord prolapse, all the followings are true EXCEРТ:
options: Cord is not seen outside the vulva.
Cord is not felt by PV examination.
Variable deceleration is present on continuous CTG monitoring.
It can kill the baby without leaving any trace of evidence.

questions.stem: A multipara presents with a prolapse non-pulsating cord. Cervix is 8 cm cervical dilatation, cephalic occipito-anterior -2 station. What should be your next step?
options: Reposit the cord above the presenting part.

questions.stem: An anemic 39 years old, G5 P5, presented with rupture uterus and intraperitoneal hemorrhage during spontaneous vaginal delivery at home. Risk factors of rupture uterus in this case include all of the followings EXCEPT:
options: Weak uterine muscles with excess fibrous tissues.
questions.explanation: The textbook lists specific risks for uterine rupture in grand multiparas (women with five or more previous deliveries), such as osteomalacia affecting the bony pelvis, false sense of security, and complications leading from malpresentations due to a pendulous abdomen and weak abdominal muscles, which can result in obstructed labor. While severe maternal anemia is a serious condition that can increase the risk of shock during hemorrhage and affect uterine contractility (predisposing to atonic PPH), it is not directly identified in the provided text as a predisposing factor for the uterine rupture itself, unlike the other options which are linked to grand multiparity or factors that lead to rupture.

questions.stem: Regarding the previous case: Best management includes:
options: Selective embolization of the uterine arteries.
questions.explanation: In cases of uterine rupture, especially when it is extensive beyond proper repair and leads to severe bleeding risking the life of the patient, abdominal hysterectomy is indicated. This is particularly relevant in elderly grand multiparas who may not desire future fertility. Given the description of rupture uterus with intraperitoneal hemorrhage in a 39-year-old G5 P5 patient, hysterectomy is often the most definitive and life-saving measure. While surgical repair of the uterus is the primary approach for less extensive ruptures, hysterectomy is preferred when repair is not feasible or bleeding is uncontrolled.

questions.stem: An 8th gravida para 7 during the 2nd stage of labor had cessation of uterine contractions and slight vaginal bleeding. Fetal head receded up. Her blood pressure became 100/60 and pulse rate became 120/minute with disturbed conscious level. What is your 1st differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The constellation of symptoms—cessation of uterine contractions, slight vaginal bleeding, recession of the fetal head to a higher pelvic station, and signs of hypovolemic shock (low blood pressure, rapid pulse, disturbed conscious level)—during labor, especially in a grand multipara (8th gravida), are classic signs and symptoms of uterine rupture. Other conditions like accidental hemorrhage (placental abruption) typically present with a tender, hard uterus, and obstructed labor with persistent tonic contractions and a pathological retraction ring.

questions.stem: What will be your next step in management in this case?
options: Ask the patient to bear down maximally aided by fundal pressure to enhance labor.
Trial of vacuum fetal head extraction.
Fluid replacement and oxytocin drip to regain uterine contractions.
Urgent Blood transfusion and immediate laparotomy.
General anesthesia to relax the constriction ring.
questions.explanation: For a diagnosed uterine rupture, the immediate management priority is resuscitation and antishock measures (which includes blood transfusion for hypovolemic shock). This must be followed by exploratory laparotomy and surgical repair to arrest the uterine bleeding and repair the torn myometrium. Attempting to enhance labor or instrumental delivery is contraindicated in cases of uterine rupture.

questions.stem: A 2nd G, P 1, previous CS had a trial for vaginal delivery. When cervix became fully dilated, uterine contractions ceased off, slight vaginal bleeding occurred and fetal head receded up. What is your 1st differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A previous Cesarean Section (CS) scar is a significant risk factor for uterine rupture. The clinical picture of cessation of uterine contractions, vaginal bleeding, and recession of the fetal head are key diagnostic signs of uterine rupture. This combination of factors, particularly the history of previous CS, strongly points to uterine rupture as the primary diagnosis.

questions.stem: In a trial for vaginal delivery after cesarean section, choose the most warning sign of impending scar dehiscence:
questions.explanation: Scar dehiscence is a form of uterine rupture. While various signs might indicate a problem, sudden onset of bleeding, which can be external vaginal bleeding, is a direct symptom of uterine rupture. Continuous vaginal blood trickling indicates active bleeding from the scar separation, making it a very direct and urgent warning sign of impending or occurring dehiscence. The textbook also mentions that no tenderness over the CS scar is a prerequisite for VBAC, implying tenderness is a warning sign. However, active bleeding (trickling) indicates a more critical progression.

questions.stem: Warning signs of impending rupture cesarean section scar include:
questions.explanation: The textbook states that for a trial of vaginal birth after Cesarean Section (VBAC), a prerequisite is 'No tenderness over the CS scar'. This implies that a tender scar is a crucial warning sign that the scar might be compromised and at risk of rupture or dehiscence. Other signs like severe vaginal bleeding or cessation of contractions are typically indicative of actual rupture, rather than impending rupture.

questions.stem: After difficult forceps application under anesthesia, the baby is delivered dead; the patient rapidly deteriorated with shock and collapse. There is mild vaginal bleeding and failed placental delivery. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Difficult obstetric manipulations, such as instrumental deliveries (e.g., forceps application), are explicitly listed as a cause of traumatic uterine rupture. The clinical presentation of a dead baby, rapid maternal deterioration with shock and collapse due to massive blood loss, mild vaginal bleeding, and failed placental delivery (the placenta may be extruded into the peritoneal cavity) are all highly consistent with a uterine rupture.

questions.stem: Rupture uterus due to difficult obstetric forceps is characterized by all the followings EXCEPT:
options: It extends from the cervix up to lateral uterine walls.
Combined abdominal-vaginal repair is mostly done.
Severe vaginal bleeding is usually present due to associated lower genital tract lacerations.
questions.explanation: The textbook defines complete rupture as a tear of all uterine layers with fetal extrusion into the peritoneal cavity, and scar dehiscence as a separation of all layers except the visceral peritoneum. However, the text does not explicitly state that rupture due to difficult obstetric forceps is usually of the complete type. Traumatic ruptures from instruments can involve complex tears that may be incomplete or extend from the cervix. Other options are generally consistent with traumatic rupture: tears can extend from the cervix laterally, broad ligament hematoma can occur with lateral tears, combined abdominal-vaginal repair is often needed for extensive tears, and lower genital tract lacerations with severe vaginal bleeding are common with instrumental delivery.

questions.stem: Regarding silent uterine rupture; all of the followings are true EXCEPT:
options: It occurs only in lower segment CS scar
May be detected accidently during performing CS.
questions.explanation: Silent uterine rupture is often synonymous with scar dehiscence, which the textbook describes as involving 'all layers except the visceral peritoneum' and the fetus being 'kept in utero with no fetal parts extruded'. This is an incomplete rupture that occurs at the lower segment CS scar and can indeed be detected accidentally during CS. Because the peritoneum remains intact and the fetus is contained, the baby is usually not as acutely affected as in a complete rupture. The term 'silent' implies that the clinical signs, including bleeding, are not typically marked or overt, making the statement that vaginal bleeding may be marked the exception for this type of rupture.

questions.stem: Predisposing factors for cervical tears include all the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: The textbook lists precipitate labor, fibrosis due to previous cerclage (under previous scarring), and instrumental delivery as explicit risk factors for cervical lacerations. While vigorous PV examinations align with rough obstetric manipulations that can cause trauma. The text states that cervical tears can occur from 'Delivery through incompletely dilated cervix as in Preterm delivery'. This means that preterm delivery is a circumstance where the cervix may be incompletely dilated, leading to a tear, rather than preterm labor itself being a predisposing factor inherent to the cervix, like rigidity or scarring.

questions.stem: Predisposing factors for perineal tears include:
questions.explanation: The textbook states that perineal lacerations can occur from 'Delivery of an LGA or a macrosomic fetus without an adequate episiotomy' and 'Instrumental delivery especially in absence of an adequate episiotomy'. Furthermore, episiotomy is performed 'when the perineum threatens to tear' to prevent extensive lacerations. Therefore, omitting an indicated episiotomy directly contributes to the occurrence of perineal tears.

questions.stem: A perineal tear involving: vaginal mucosa, perineal skin, transverse perineal muscles and external anal sphincter, is:
questions.explanation: According to the textbook's classification of lacerations, a third-degree tear involves 'the vagina, perineal muscles, and the anal sphincter'. The description of involving the vaginal mucosa, perineal skin, transverse perineal muscles, and specifically the external anal sphincter, precisely matches this definition. A first-degree tear involves only mucosa, a second-degree tear includes the muscles of the perineal body, and a fourth-degree tear extends to the anal mucosa.

cards.front: What is the first sign of pregnancy?
cards.back: Amenorrhea.

cards.front: What physiological cardiovascular changes occur during pregnancy?
cards.back: Blood volume increases by 50% (peaking at 28-32 weeks), BP drops mid-trimester, cardiac output increases by 40%, and the apex beat shifts upwards and outwards.

cards.front: What causes the physiological drop in hemoglobin during the second trimester?
cards.back: Hemodilution, due to a greater increase in plasma volume compared to red blood cell mass.

cards.front: What physiological changes occur to the thyroid during pregnancy?
cards.back: Total T3 and T4 levels increase due to higher thyroid-binding globulin (TBG), but free T3 and T4 levels remain unchanged. A physiologic goiter may also occur.

cards.front: Which hormone is responsible for keeping the uterus quiescent (inhibited) during pregnancy?
cards.back: Progesterone.

cards.front: What is the decidua?
cards.back: It is the secretory endometrium of the uterus during pregnancy, prepared for implantation.

cards.front: List some warning signs and symptoms during pregnancy.
cards.back: Severe headache, blurring of vision, epigastric pain, vaginal bleeding, a gush of fluid, or diminished fetal movements.

cards.front: What blood pressure reading defines preeclampsia?
What is the definitive treatment for preeclampsia?
cards.back: Termination of pregnancy.

cards.front: What are the components of HELLP syndrome?
cards.back:
Hemolysis,
Elevated Liver enzymes, and
Low Platelets.

cards.front: What is the primary action of Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO4) in severe pre-eclampsia?
cards.back: It suppresses the Central Nervous System (CNS) to prevent and control convulsions. Its main function is not the reduction of blood pressure.

cards.front: What is the antidote for MgSO4 toxicity?
cards.back: Calcium gluconate.

cards.front: What are the parameters assessed on a CTG (Cardiotocogram)?
cards.back: Baseline fetal heart rate, beat-to-beat variability, accelerations, and decelerations.

cards.front: What do the different types of decelerations on a CTG indicate?
cards.back:
Early: Head Compression.
Variable: Cord Compression.
Late: Placental insufficiency / fetal hypoxia (This is the most serious type).

cards.front: What are the two types of Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR)?
cards.back: Symmetrical (TYPE I) and Asymmetrical (TYPE II).

cards.front: What is the most common complication for a baby born to a mother with poorly managed diabetes?
cards.back: Macrosomia.

cards.front: What are potential complications of fetal macrosomia?
cards.back: Shoulder dystocia and fetal hypoglycemia after birth.

cards.front: What congenital anomaly is most specific to infants of diabetic mothers?
cards.back: Sacral agenesis (Caudal Regression Syndrome).

cards.front: At what serum bilirubin level does a neonate become at risk for kernicterus?
cards.back: Approximately >20 mg/dL.

cards.front: When is amniocentesis typically performed and for what indications?
cards.back: It is performed between 14-16 weeks of gestation for indications like karyotyping and checking bilirubin levels.

cards.front: What is the most common cause of antepartum hemorrhage (APH)?
cards.back: Placental abruption.

cards.front: What is the most common clinical presentation of placental abruption?
cards.back: Pain.

cards.front: What is the most common clinical presentation of placenta previa?
cards.back: Asymptomatic. The second most common is painless vaginal bleeding.

cards.front: What is the most common cause of primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?
cards.back: Uterine atony.

cards.front: How is postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) defined by blood volume?
cards.back: Loss of >500 cc after a vaginal delivery or >1000 cc after a Cesarean section.

cards.front: What is the most important difference between true and false labor pains?
cards.back: True labor involves progressive cervical dilatation and the pain is not relieved by analgesia.

cards.front: What are the 5 criteria of the Bishop Score?
cards.back: Dilatation, effacement, consistency, position, and station.

cards.front: In which stage of labor is a partogram used?
cards.back: Only in the first stage of labor to track cervical dilation, effacement, and station.

cards.front: Describe the leg positions in complete, frank, and incomplete breech presentations.
cards.back:
Complete: Flexed hips and knees.
Frank: Flexed hips and extended knees.
Incomplete (Footling/Knee): Extended hips.

cards.front: What is the denominator in a breech presentation?
cards.back: The sacrum.

cards.front: Compare a mediolateral episiotomy with a median episiotomy.
cards.back:
Mediolateral: More bleeding and more dyspareunia, but no anal sphincter injury.
Median: Better cosmetic result and healing with less bleeding, but a higher risk of anal sphincter affection.

cards.front: What is the most common complication of obstructed labor in a multiparous woman?
cards.back: Uterine Rupture.

cards.front: What is the most common cause of acute uterine inversion?
cards.back: Rapid traction on the cord before full placental separation.

cards.front: How is a retained placenta defined based on time?
cards.back: When the placenta is not delivered within 30 minutes of childbirth.

cards.front: What is the most common cause for a Cesarean section?
cards.back: A previous CS.

cards.front: Within what timeframe should an Rh-negative mother receive Anti-D immunoglobulin after delivering an Rh-positive baby?
cards.back: Within 72 hours.

cards.front: What is the management for a threatened abortion?
cards.back: Physical and mental rest.

cards.front: What is the most common complication of twin pregnancy?
cards.back: Preterm delivery.

cards.front: What is the complaint associated with a septate uterus and what is its management?
cards.back: The complaint is recurrent abortion, and management is hysteroscopic septal resection.

cards.front: What is the complaint associated with a bicornuate uterus?
cards.back: Preterm labour.

cards.front: In a pregnant patient with red degeneration of a fibroid, what is the main complaint and management?
cards.back: The main complaint is pain, and management is conservative with analgesics and fluids. Myomectomy is contraindicated.

cards.front: What is the drug of choice for treating hyperthyroidism during pregnancy?
cards.back: Propylthiouracil (PTU).

cards.front: Why is radioactive iodine contraindicated for treating hyperthyroidism in pregnancy?
cards.back: Because it can cross the placenta and destroy the fetal thyroid gland.
